source.title: Poaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons
source.citation: From: Walsh, N.G. (1994). Poaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Clusters of spikelets (racemes) distinctly stalked and becoming free from spathes; fertile spikelets densely rusty-pubescent; 2 of the 4 involucral spikelets pedicellate; culms robust, often 1.5 m or more high; rare, probably naturalized grass

Clusters of spikelets (racemes) virtually sessile, remaining enclosed at the base by the spathes; fertile spikelets glabrous except near apex; involucral spikelets all sessile; culms rarely exceeding 1 m high; common, widespread grass
